sessions.title: JavaScript that doesn’t hurt your feelings
sessions.description: JavaScript just had its 20th birthday this year and it has come a long way. But many fail to recognise this and still code like it’s 1999. This talk will take you through my favourite features of recent JavaScript editions, shows you how to use them in your project today and will give you an outlook of even better things to come.

sessions.title: SVG in motion
sessions.description: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) are taking over a lot of our design tools by offering us more flexibility over those tools. In this talk, we will cover everything we need to know before attempting to animate SVGs, including animation gotchas, how-tos and pre-animation requisites such as optimization and embedding, among others, and how each of those affects the animation process.

sessions.title: Operations: a developer's guide
sessions.description: An introduction to the web ops skills that will help you be a better developer. What you need to know about virtualisation, containerisation and wrangling servers, and some tools we use that might make development easier. I spent two years on the infrastructure team so you don't have to!

sessions.title: The Web Audio Phenomenon that Shall Not Be Named
sessions.description: Natural languages have many nooks and crannies, but there's a particular rabbit hole that will obsess you from the start. In this talk, you'll learn about the oddest psychological phenomenon ever to be thrown at getUserMedia and the odd parallels between learning human, natural languages and learning programming languages.

sessions.title: How to win at mobile accessibility
sessions.description: The mobile web-vs-native debate rages on–who's winning? How can we create mobile experiences that are accessible and reliable to people with disabilities? In this talk, we'll dive head-first into the mobile debate and reemerge informed on how we can use our skills as web developers to create brilliant mobile apps.

sessions.title: You should use <insert library/framework>, it's the bestestest!
sessions.description: "You should use [insert library or framework here], it's the bestestest!" is pretty standard modern web development chatter. But how do you separate the hype from the reality? Let's have a look at how we can gather data to assess the fit of code to your projects.

sessions.title: Code Calligrams
sessions.description:
Programming is art: It is like painting, but instead of drawing on a canvas we populate computer screens with colours. And rather than using brushes, we combine bits and bytes to trace an ever-changing flow of images.

In this talk, you'll be introduced to the art of "Creative Coding" and how to generate beautiful new worlds, using nothing else than the languages of the Web.

sessions.title: A Talk about Everything
sessions.description: Software influences the lives of billions of humans every day. As people working on it, we face a broad variety of challenges – and we have a responsibility towards each of these humans. Let's take a look at the status of software development today, and see what each of us can do to act according to this responsibility.

workshops.title: Advanced CSS Layout Training
workshops.description: CSS Layout has been stuck somewhere around 2006 for several years. We have had to attempt complex layout using tools such as floats and positioning. These methods never designed for complex page and application layout. However things are changing and it’s a great time to take a look at the layout methods that are now part of modern CSS, and those coming in the very near future.
workshops.extendedDescription:
This workshop is designed for designers and developers who already have a good working knowledge of HTML and CSS. We will cover a range of CSS methods for achieving layout, from those you are safe to use right now even if you need to support older version of Internet Explorer through to things that while still classed as experimental, are likely to ship in browsers in the coming months. The aim is to teach you some tips that I’ve learned working on real projects, alongside sharing some of the exciting things that I’ve been experimenting with as I look into emerging specifications.

This will be a practical workshop, we will work through code examples together, and you’ll have those worked examples to take away to experiment with further or to share with your team.

topics.title: Learning from the past
topics.description: What can we take from older layout methods that might help us build layouts that also work well in older browsers?

topics.title: CSS Layout today
topics.description: Looking at some of the modules that have good support today - multiple column layout, flexbox and CSS Shapes

topics.title: Just Landing
topics.description: CSS Grid Layout will bring us a fit-for-purpose layout method for the first time. We will find out how Grid works alongside Flexbox and the Box Alignment Module to create a new system of layout.

topics.title: Experimental
topics.description: What else is hiding in the CSS specifications? How can we encourage implementation of the things we would like to see land?

topics.title: Building the future
topics.description: Some thoughts and practical ideas on how we bring these techniques together to build modern layouts that don’t lock out the unfortunate users of old browsers

workshops.title: Mastering browser devtools

topics.title: Network
topics.description: What's slow, why and the detail behind a request

topics.title: Source
topics.description: How to make DevTools your development IDE

topics.title: Performance
topics.description: How to read and investigate rendering issues

topics.title: Mobile
topics.description: Using the tools you know to debug tiny machines

workshops.description: Sure, you've moved past "alert" debugging and discovered console.log, but did you know you can replay XHR requests instead of having to repeat your steps to make the request? Or that you can proxy your local server through a browser configuration so your mobile phone can see it? This workshop is dedicated to learning the native developer tools baked in to the browser to make our life a little more bearable.
workshops.extendedDescription:
We will look at features of Chrome DevTools, what's available in Firefox debugging suite. We'll also look at remote mobile debugging using native tools and also look at the alternative tools where native support isn't available.

The workshop will mostly be about the foundation of debugging techniques, which apply way beyond just a single browser's debugger tool, but will raise your expectation of all web debugging environments.
